articles.headline: Car Keys Could Go the Way of Tail Fins
articles.snippet: At the New York International Auto Show, doors swing open to reveal push-button starters — no key necessary.
articles.abstract: At the New York International Auto Show, doors swing open to reveal push-button starters — no key necessary.
articles.lead_paragraph: Are we about to lose our car keys for good?

articles.headline: Combat, With Limits, Looms for Hybrid Aircraft
articles.snippet: Critics say the V-22 Osprey’s limitations may make it vulnerable to attack.
articles.abstract: Critics say the V-22 Osprey’s limitations may make it vulnerable to attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Marine Corps said yesterday that the V-22 Osprey, a hybrid aircraft with a troubled past, will be sent to Iraq this September, where it will see combat for the first time.

articles.headline: Hip Surgery With a Future
articles.snippet: An interim approach to total hip replacement is offering an alternative that still leaves open the possibility of successfully receiving an artificial hip later in life.
articles.abstract: An interim approach to total hip replacement is offering an alternative that still leaves open the possibility of successfully receiving an artificial hip later in life.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hip replacement, an operation that about 300,000 Americans undergo each year, is one of the great success stories of modern medicine.

articles.headline: E-Mail Identified G.O.P. Candidates for Justice Jobs
articles.snippet: A Justice Department message appears to be at odds with officials’ repeated statements that no successors were selected before several U.S. attorneys were dismissed.
articles.abstract: A Justice Department message appears to be at odds with officials’ repeated statements that no successors were selected before several U.S. attorneys were dismissed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 13 — A Justice Department e-mail message released on Friday shows that the former chief of staff to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales proposed replacement candidates for United States attorneys nearly a year before they were dismissed in December 2006. The department has repeatedly stated that no successors were selected before the dismissals.
articles.byline: By David Johnston and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: A Building for Diller by Gehry
articles.snippet: With its billowing sheets of curved glass, its partly white windows, and the world’s largest high-def screen in its  expansive lobby, the new headquarters of IAC is unlike anything in Manhattan.
articles.abstract: With its billowing sheets of curved glass, its partly white windows, and the world’s largest high-def screen in its  expansive lobby, the new headquarters of IAC is unlike anything in Manhattan.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was raining hard Thursday morning as I headed to the new headquarters of IAC/InterActiveCorp, Barry Diller’s “Internet conglomerate,” as he likes to call it. Although some employees had been working there since February — “the guinea pigs,” joked Jason Stewart, IAC’s chief administrative officer — the building had been officially open for business less than two weeks.

articles.headline: Say Good Night, Bandwidth Hog
articles.snippet: Comcast is warning its customers to limit their bandwidth or face a one-year termination of service.
articles.abstract: Comcast is warning its customers to limit their bandwidth or face a one-year termination of service.
articles.lead_paragraph: AN article in PC Magazine last week revealed that customers across the country have received letters from Comcast warning them to limit their bandwidth consumption or face a one-year termination of service.

articles.headline: Wellesley Class Sees ‘One of Us’ Bearing Standard
articles.snippet: For her classmates, Hillary Rodham Clinton’s quest to become the first female president is a generational mirror.
articles.abstract: For her classmates, Hillary Rodham Clinton’s quest to become the first female president is a generational mirror.
articles.lead_paragraph: For her Wellesley classmates, Hillary Clinton’s quest to become the first female president is a generational mirror. Some like what they see; others are less certain.

articles.headline: Sales Abroad Propping Up the Economy
articles.snippet: A weakening economy is getting some relief from abroad as American companies step up their sales to foreigners, the latest data, released Friday, suggests.
articles.abstract: A weakening economy is getting some relief from abroad as American companies step up their sales to foreigners, the latest data, released Friday, suggests.
articles.lead_paragraph: A weakening economy is getting some relief from abroad as American companies step up their sales to foreigners, the latest data, released yesterday, suggests.

articles.headline: Guardedly Kicking the Tires on Chrysler
articles.snippet: The effort by DaimlerChrysler to find a buyer for Chrysler is becoming a drawn-out, complicated process beset by issues including debt, health costs and unions.
articles.abstract: The effort by DaimlerChrysler to find a buyer for Chrysler is becoming a drawn-out, complicated process beset by issues including debt, health costs and unions.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, April 13  Dieter Zetsche, the chief executive of DaimlerChrysler, found out last summer that selling cars as a TV pitchman is harder than it looks.

articles.headline: Google Buys an Online Ad Firm for $3.1 Billion
articles.snippet: Google agreed to its largest acquisition Friday, reaching a deal to purchase DoubleClick for almost double what it paid for YouTube last year.
articles.abstract: Google agreed to its largest acquisition Friday, reaching a deal to purchase DoubleClick for almost double what it paid for YouTube last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google agreed to its largest acquisition yesterday, reaching a deal to purchase DoubleClick, the online advertising company, from two private equity firms for $3.1 billion in cash, almost double what it paid for YouTube last year. And perhaps just as important, the deal kept DoubleClick from the hands of Microsoft.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: CA Says Its Founder Aided Fraud
articles.snippet: The software company accused its founder of masterminding a huge accounting fraud.
articles.abstract: The software company accused its founder of masterminding a huge accounting fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: The Pilotless Plane That Only Looks Like Child’s Play
articles.snippet: During the last several years, unmanned aerial vehicles — known as U.A.V.’s —  have amassed unusual political firepower.
articles.abstract: During the last several years, unmanned aerial vehicles — known as U.A.V.’s —  have amassed unusual political firepower.
articles.lead_paragraph: IF you’re the type of shopper who spends billions of dollars on lethal military gadgets, and you’re ever invited to visit General Atomics Aeronautical Systems — the small, privately held San Diego company that has quickly become one of the military industry’s most celebrated businesses — take a bit of advice: accept a ride on the corporate jet.

articles.headline: Militia Talks Could Reshape Conflict in Darfur
articles.snippet: Representatives of rebel groups are discussing a military alliance of Arab and non-Arab tribes against the Sudanese government.
articles.abstract: Representatives of rebel groups are discussing a military alliance of Arab and non-Arab tribes against the Sudanese government.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABÉCHÉ, Chad  The two rebels sitting together on a dry riverbed could just as easily have been sworn enemies, perched on opposite sides of an abyss that has cleaved their homeland in two.

articles.headline: With Eye on Iran, Rivals Also Want Nuclear Power
articles.snippet: Officials in Middle Eastern governments have warned of the possibility of “a grave and destructive nuclear arms race in the region.”
articles.abstract: Officials in Middle Eastern governments have warned of the possibility of “a grave and destructive nuclear arms race in the region.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, the leaders of Saudi Arabia told international atomic regulators that they could foresee no need for the kingdom to develop nuclear power. Today, they are scrambling to hire atomic contractors, buy nuclear hardware and build support for a regional system of reactors.
articles.byline: By William J. Broad and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: ‘For Sale’ May Mean ‘You Lose’
articles.snippet: Auctions make money, but how much goes to shareholders?
articles.abstract: Auctions make money, but how much goes to shareholders?
articles.lead_paragraph: THERE are quiet fire sales occurring inside the corporate bankruptcy world that hurt bondholders and other creditors while, in many cases, enriching insiders at failed companies.

articles.headline: Stung by a Fraud Indictment, a Power Broker Punches Back
articles.snippet: David A. Stockman, President Ronald Reagan’s budget director, is facing a trial on fraud charges.
articles.abstract: David A. Stockman, President Ronald Reagan’s budget director, is facing a trial on fraud charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: ASPEN, Colo.  David A. Stockman is trying to unwind at his second home here after another long day spent scouring legal documents. Dinner at a restaurant with his wife, Jennifer, has been a balm, to say nothing of the big glass of scotch he has nursed throughout the evening.

articles.headline: McCain Sees ‘No Plan B’ for Iraq War
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain said in an interview that the buildup of U.S. forces in Iraq represented the only viable option to avoid failure.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain said in an interview that the buildup of U.S. forces in Iraq represented the only viable option to avoid failure.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, APRIL 13 — Senator John McCain said that the buildup of American forces in Iraq represented the only viable option to avoid failure in Iraq and that he had yet to identify an effective fallback if the current strategy failed.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Adam Nagourney

articles.headline: Aging: Disease or Business Opportunity?
articles.snippet: The market for drugs to control and treat diseases of aging and for appearance-related products and services is expected to reach $71 billion a year by 2009.
articles.abstract: The market for drugs to control and treat diseases of aging and for appearance-related products and services is expected to reach $71 billion a year by 2009.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR four days last December, America’s pleasure dome in the desert, Las Vegas, played host to a convention dedicated to the proposition that growing old is “a treatable medical condition.”

articles.headline: Marines’ Actions in Afghanistan Called Excessive
articles.snippet: American marines reacted to a bomb ambush with excessive force, shooting  bystanders, a report said.
articles.abstract: American marines reacted to a bomb ambush with excessive force, shooting  bystanders, a report said.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan, April 14  American marines reacted to a bomb ambush with excessive force in eastern Afghanistan last month, hitting groups of bystanders and vehicles with machine-gun fire in a rampage that covered 10 miles of highway and left 12 civilians dead, including an infant and three elderly men, according to a report published by an Afghan human rights commission on Saturday.

articles.headline: Attacks Surge as Iraq Militants Overshadow City
articles.snippet: Baquba has emerged as a magnet for insurgents and, perhaps, the next major headache for the U.S. military.
articles.abstract: Baquba has emerged as a magnet for insurgents and, perhaps, the next major headache for the U.S. military.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAQUBA, Iraq — They maneuver in squads, like the American infantrymen they try to kill. One squad fires furiously so another can attack from a better position. They operate in bad weather, knowing American helicopters and surveillance drones are grounded. Some carry G.P.S. receivers so mortar teams can calculate the coordinates of American armored vehicles. They kidnap and massacre police officers.

articles.headline: Diversions for the Jet Set
articles.snippet: The quality of entertainment is a factor in choosing an airline, and sophisticated distractions can make a long haul feel like the good life.
articles.abstract: The quality of entertainment is a factor in choosing an airline, and sophisticated distractions can make a long haul feel like the good life.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOU wouldn’t know it from that distant blurry movie on your airline’s old overhead screen, but a major revolution is going on with in-flight entertainment.

articles.headline: A Trophy Mag Wears Camouflage
articles.snippet: Field & Stream received four nominations in the National Magazine Awards, putting it in the front ranks of magazine journalism.
articles.abstract: Field & Stream received four nominations in the National Magazine Awards, putting it in the front ranks of magazine journalism.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sid Evans, the editor of Field & Stream, is hardly the only editor in the ferocious world of Manhattan publishing with a reputation for taking no prisoners. But he is the only one with the temerity to actually hang the heads on the wall.

articles.headline: Getting the C.E.O. Treatment at Conferences
articles.snippet: In exclusive settings, people are likely to feel appreciated and worthy of more than a PowerPoint presentation.
articles.abstract: In exclusive settings, people are likely to feel appreciated and worthy of more than a PowerPoint presentation.
articles.lead_paragraph: FIRST there were boutique hotels — small, private, luxurious and impressive. They were expensive, but that was not an issue for the people frequenting them.

articles.headline: What’s Cooking in First Class?
articles.snippet: Eating light or indulging, you can bet it’s not peanuts.
articles.abstract: Eating light or indulging, you can bet it’s not peanuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN it comes to food, airlines seem to be going all out for the well-paid business traveler.

articles.headline: AOL Founder Hopes to Build New Giant Among a Bevy of Health Care Web Sites
articles.snippet: Stephen M. Case, who  plans to unveil RevolutionHealth.com, says the time is ripe for a dominant health care brand.
articles.abstract: Stephen M. Case, who  plans to unveil RevolutionHealth.com, says the time is ripe for a dominant health care brand.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stephen M. Case wants to be America’s doctor, courtesy of the Web.

articles.headline: In a Troubled Time, a New Business Magazine
articles.snippet: Portfolio, the glossy new business magazine from Condé Nast, is hoping to capitalize where other bigger magazines have faltered.
articles.abstract: Portfolio, the glossy new business magazine from Condé Nast, is hoping to capitalize where other bigger magazines have faltered.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joanne Lipman, the editor of Portfolio, the new business magazine from Condé Nast, tapped gently last Monday on the door of David Carey, the publisher, and then burst into his bright Midtown corner office.

articles.headline: Russia Tries to Save Polar Bears With Legal Hunt
articles.snippet: Scientists, environmentalists and native villagers express hope that a legal hunt could rein in rampant poaching.
articles.abstract: Scientists, environmentalists and native villagers express hope that a legal hunt could rein in rampant poaching.
articles.lead_paragraph: VANKAREM, Russia — Here on the frozen edge of the country’s Arctic expanse, where a changing climate has brought polar bears into greater contact with people, Russia has embraced a counterintuitive method of trying to preserve the creatures: hunting them, legally.

articles.headline: I.R.S. Audits Middle Class More Often, More Quickly
articles.snippet: The I.R.S. has nearly tripled audits of tax returns filed by people making $25,000 to $100,000 since 2000.
articles.abstract: The I.R.S. has nearly tripled audits of tax returns filed by people making $25,000 to $100,000 since 2000.
articles.lead_paragraph: Middle-class Americans, listen up: the I.R.S. is much more likely to audit you this year. Those caught cheating can expect to pay about $4,100 more on average in income taxes.

articles.headline: Sallie Mae, Mired in Controversy Over Loans, Is Under Siege
articles.snippet: The nation’s largest provider of student loans is under siege on the political and economic fronts.
articles.abstract: The nation’s largest provider of student loans is under siege on the political and economic fronts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Standing before a group of student lending executives in late 2005, Representative John A. Boehner, then chairman of the House Education Committee, vowed he would keep their interests in mind as legislation made its way though Congress.

articles.headline: Negotiators Say Sallie Mae to Be Sold for $25 Billion
articles.snippet: The nation’s largest education lender agreed to be sold to JP Morgan Chase, Bank of America and two private equity firms.
articles.abstract: The nation’s largest education lender agreed to be sold to JP Morgan Chase, Bank of America and two private equity firms.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sallie Mae agreed late last night to be sold to JP Morgan Chase, Bank of America and two private equity firms for $25 billion, said people involved in the negotiations.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Jennifer 8. Lee
